title: Sri Lanka stocks suffer first weekly loss in four weeks; see foreign inflows
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka stocks suffered first weekly slip in four weeks on the week ended on Friday (5) as the government tax hikes and political instability concerns dampened investor sentiment, stockbrokers said.

The All Share Price Index (ASPI) fell 3.14 percent for the week after gaining in the previous three weeks, the Colombo Stock Exchange data showed. The market on Friday ended at 8,054.77, its lowest close since May 12.
“Investors are waiting for a bargain hunting with some some positive news, but there is nothing so far,” a stockbroker said.
“The government’s fiscal reforms may be good, but it is going to hit the profitability of the businesses in the short to ,medium term.”

Sri Lanka Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe this week implemented a raft of tax hikes for imports while the country is also experiencing record high fuel prices. He also raised the value added tax (VAT) to 12 percent from 8 percent.
Though higher taxes are good for state finances and an International Monetary Fund deal, but they will hit earnings.

The week saw the highest weekly foreign inflows in two months with a volume of 359.6 million rupees’ worth of shares. It was the first weekly foreign inflow in the lat four weeks and the highest sine the week ended on April 8.
The market has so far lost 1.1 percent in June after gaining 6 percent in May. It lost 23 percent in April and 14.5 percent in March.
The market has lost 34.1 percent so far this year after being one of the world’s best stock markets with an 80 percent return last year when large volumes of money were printed.
The daily average market turnover was 1.4 billion rupees during this week, around a third of this year’s average daily turnover of 3.9 billion rupees.
Sri Lanka’s sovereign default default and rupee depreciation also have hurt the sentiment.

The default has already led the rating agencies to downgrade the island nation’s rating to restricted/selective default rating. Investors are also concerned over the steep fall of the rupee from 200 to 370 levels so far in 2022. (Colombo/Jun 04/2022)
